jsem-problems.comment: Japanese Semantics Test Suite (Beta version, last modified on May 30, 2015) created by Ai Kawazoe, Ribeka Tanaka, Koji Mineshima and Daisuke Bekki, 2015.
The format of this file is based on those of FraCaS textual inference problem set by Bill MacCartney and MutiFraCaS sets by Robin Cooper.

This Beta version contains textual inference tests involving GQs, which corresponds to Generalized Quantifier section in FraCaS test suite (Cooper et al.1996). Note that not all of the tests are literal translation of FraCaS. We created original Japanese data for some FraCas tests which cannot be translated into natural Japanese sentences. One or more tests are linked to a FraCaS entry when necessary.

problem.phenomena: generalized quantifier, conservativity

p.script: あるイタリア人が世界最高のテノール歌手になった。
p.english: An Italian became the world's greatest tenor.

h.script: 世界最高のテノール歌手になったイタリア人がいた。
h.english: There was an Italian who became the world's greatest tenor.

problem.phenomena: generalized quantifier, conservativity, Q-no NC

p.script: 一人一人のイタリア人テノール歌手が偉大な歌手になりたがっている。
p.english: Each Italian tenor wants to be great.

p.script: 何人かのイタリア人テノール歌手は偉大である。
p.english: Some Italian tenors are great.

h.script: 偉大な歌手になりたがっているイタリア人テノール歌手がいる。
h.english: There are Italian tenors who want to be great.

problem.note: comments for FraCaS by Bill MacCartney: Note that second premise is unnecessary and irrelevant.
AK: A literal translation for "to be great" is "偉大になりたがっている," but it sounds slightly unnatural. The meaning of "偉大な歌手になりたがっている" in P1 and H is "to be a great singer."

problem.phenomena: generalized quantifier, conservativity, negation

p.script: どの偉大なテノール歌手も謙虚ではない。
p.english: No really great tenors are modest.

h.script: 謙虚で偉大なテノール歌手がいる。
h.english: There are really great tenors who are modest.

problem.note: AK: I omit the translation of "really" from P1 and H since it makes the sentences unnatural.

AK: There are no Japanese nominal expressions which correspond to monotone-decreasing GQs such as "no N" or "neither N." The same semantic contents can be expressed with a combination of a universal quantificational NP and a negation of a predicate.

h.english: There are really great tenors who are modest.

p.english: Neither leading tenor comes cheap.

h.english: Pavarotti is a leading tenor who comes cheap.

problem.note: AK: There is no Japanese nominal expression corresponds to "neither N." The translation of P1 above, with a floating quantifier-like expression "dotira-mo" (both) and negation, has the same meaning as original.

problem.note: AK: I translated the auxiliary "will" as "yotei-da" (It is planned that...). "Daroo" (a standard translation for "will") or some other verbal suffixes with a similar meaning sound unnatural in relative clauses.

problem.phenomena: generalized quantifier, conservativity, cleft

problem.note: AK: A literal translation for "at most two tenors," "せいぜい二人のテノール歌手," sounds awkward (#せいぜい二人のテノール歌手が出演料を慈善事業に寄付するだろう). I used cleft construction to make the sentence more natural.

problem.note: AK: There are no Japanese nominal expressions which correspond to monotone-decreasing GQs such as "no N" or "neither N." The same semantic contents can be expressed with a combination of a universal quantificational NP and a negation of a predicate.

p.script: 多くのイギリスの代表者が調査から興味深い結果を得た。
p.english: Many British delegates obtained interesting results from the survey.

h.script: 多くの代表者が調査から興味深い結果を得た。
h.english: Many delegates obtained interesting results from the survey.

problem.note: （MacCartney氏のFraCaS原文に対するコメント）This answer seems dubious to me. Apparently the FraCaS people interpret "many" as denoting a large proportion, whereas I interpret it as denoting a large absolute number. That is, if "many" is regarded as a binary generalized quantifier, they want to say it's non-monotone in the first argument (and upward-monotone in the second), whereas I would say it's upward-monotone in both arguments. Note that this problem is exactly the inverse of problem fracas-72.

p.english: A few committee members are from Scandinavia.

problem.phenomena: generalized quantifier, monotonicity (downwards on first argument), negation

p.script: 南ヨーロッパ出身の委員はほとんどいない。
p.english: Few committee members are from southern Europe.

h.script: 南ヨーロッパ出身の女性委員はほとんどいない。
h.english: Few female committee members are from southern Europe.

problem.note: AK: There is no nominal expression corresponds to "few N" in Japanese. The translation of P1 above has the same meaning as original.

（MacCartney氏のFraCaS原文に対するコメント） Note that this problem is exactly the inverse of problem fracas-60. If the answer is "yes", then apparently the FraCaS people interpret "few" as denoting a small absolute number, rather than a small proportion. That is, if "few" is regarded as a binary generalized quantifier, they want to say it's downward-monotone in the first argument, rather than non-monotone. Contrast this with the treatment of "many" in fracas-56 and fracas-72, which is apparently interpreted to be non-monotone in its first argument.

problem.note: note in the original FraCaS: Yes, if both commissioners are female; otherwise there are more than two commissioners.
